title: Malachi Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Malachi chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Malachi Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Malachi Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is the burden of the word of the LORD to Israel given by?
options: Malachi
Moses
Elijah
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Malachi
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:1 states that the burden of the word of the LORD to Israel is by Malachi.

questions.question: According to Malachi 1:2, whom did the LORD say He loved?
options: Esau
Jacob
Edom
Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:2 says the LORD loved Jacob, not Esau.

questions.question: What did the LORD say He did to Esau?
options: Loved him
Laid his mountains and heritage waste
Blessed him
Protected him
questions.correctAnswer: Laid his mountains and heritage waste
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:3 states that the LORD hated Esau and laid his mountains and heritage waste.

questions.question: What will happen to Edom's attempt to rebuild the desolate places, according to the LORD?
options: They shall build and prosper
They shall build but the LORD will throw down
They will be blessed
They shall be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: They shall build but the LORD will throw down
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:4 says Edom will build but the LORD will throw down what they build.

questions.question: What will your eyes see according to Malachi 1:5?
options: The LORD will be magnified from the border of Israel
Destruction of Israel
The fall of Edom
Great famine
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will be magnified from the border of Israel
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:5 states that your eyes will see the LORD magnified from the border of Israel.

questions.question: To whom is the LORD speaking when He asks about honor and fear?
options: The priests
The kings
The prophets
The people of Edom
questions.correctAnswer: The priests
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6 addresses the priests who despise the LORD's name.

questions.question: What kind of bread do the priests offer on the LORD's altar according to Malachi 1:7?
options: Pure bread
Polluted bread
Unleavened bread
Fresh bread
questions.correctAnswer: Polluted bread
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:7 says the priests offer polluted bread on the LORD's altar.

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 1:8 states that offering the blind, lame, and sick for sacrifice is acceptable to the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:8 clearly says offering the blind, lame, and sick is evil and not acceptable.

questions.question: Who does the LORD say will not accept the people's offerings because they have no honor or fear?
options: The priests
The LORD of hosts
The governors
The people of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6-10 shows the LORD of hosts will not accept offerings due to lack of honor and fear.

questions.question: According to Malachi 1:11, from where to where will the LORD's name be great?
options: From the east to the west
From the rising of the sun to the going down
From the north to the south
From Zion to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: From the rising of the sun to the going down
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:11 says the LORD’s name will be great from the rising to the going down of the sun.

questions.question: What have the people said that profanes the table of the LORD?
options: The table of the LORD is polluted
The table of the LORD is holy
The table is clean
The table is blessed
questions.correctAnswer: The table of the LORD is polluted
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:12 states the people have profaned the LORD's table by saying it is polluted.

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 1:13 says the people offered good and perfect sacrifices to the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:13 says the people offered torn, lame, and sick sacrifices, which the LORD did not accept.

questions.question: What curse does the LORD pronounce in Malachi 1:14?
options: Curse on the deceiver who sacrifices corrupt things
Curse on the priests
Curse on Edom
Curse on the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Curse on the deceiver who sacrifices corrupt things
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:14 says cursed is the deceiver who sacrifices corrupt things to the LORD.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Malachi 1:6 says, 'A son honoureth his father, and a servant his ______.'
options: master
king
neighbor
friend
questions.correctAnswer: master
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6 states, 'A son honoureth his father, and a servant his master.'

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 1:10 says the LORD has pleasure in the offerings of the people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:10 states the LORD has no pleasure in the offerings and will not accept them.

medium.title: Malachi Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Malachi Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Malachi 1 teach us about honoring God in our daily work and worship?
options: By offering pure and acceptable sacrifices to the Lord
By neglecting the altar as unimportant
By offering blind and lame animals as sacrifices
By saying the table of the Lord is contemptible
questions.correctAnswer: By offering pure and acceptable sacrifices to the Lord
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:7-8 rebukes offering blind or lame sacrifices and calls it evil, while Malachi 1:11 emphasizes that God's name shall be great and pure offerings shall be given. This teaches the importance of honoring God with sincerity and integrity in worship.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged because others treat God’s house with contempt. Based on Malachi 1, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God’s name will be glorified among all nations
God has abandoned His people
It is acceptable to offer defective sacrifices
God does not care about the altar
questions.correctAnswer: God’s name will be glorified among all nations
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:11 promises that from sunrise to sunset, God's name will be great among the Gentiles, showing that despite contempt, God's glory and worship will prevail universally.

questions.question: How does Malachi 1 instruct us about integrity and honesty in our work and commitments?
options: Do not deceive God by offering corrupt or defective sacrifices
Offer whatever is easiest to give without concern
Avoid making vows or commitments to God
Sacrifice only when it is convenient
questions.correctAnswer: Do not deceive God by offering corrupt or defective sacrifices
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:14 condemns those who deceive God by offering corrupt sacrifices, teaching the importance of honesty and integrity in fulfilling our promises to God.

questions.question: How does Malachi 1 challenge us to reflect on our attitude towards God's commands and worship?
options: We should not treat worship as a weariness or burden
Worship is optional when we are tired
God accepts sacrifices even if given reluctantly
It is acceptable to despise God's name
questions.correctAnswer: We should not treat worship as a weariness or burden
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:13 rebukes the attitude of weariness and contempt towards offerings, emphasizing that God desires heartfelt worship and reverence, not mere duty.

questions.question: A believer asks how Malachi 1 teaches about humility before God and those in authority. What would you say?
options: Honor God as a father and fear Him as a master
Challenge God’s authority openly
Ignore God’s commands when inconvenient
Treat God as a servant
questions.correctAnswer: Honor God as a father and fear Him as a master
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6 compares honoring a father and fearing a master with honoring God, encouraging humility and respect toward God’s authority in our lives.

questions.question: How does Malachi 1 teach us about perseverance and faithfulness in trials related to family heritage or identity?
options: God’s love and choice are sovereign despite outward conditions
God favors the wealthy and powerful only
Family heritage guarantees God's favor
God loves all equally without distinction
questions.correctAnswer: God’s love and choice are sovereign despite outward conditions
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:2-3 illustrates God’s sovereign choice of Jacob over Esau, showing that God’s love is not based on heritage but His purpose, encouraging trust and perseverance.

questions.question: What does Malachi 1 teach about prayer and seeking God’s grace when we have failed to honor Him properly?
options: We should sincerely beseech God for grace and forgiveness
Prayer is unnecessary if we fail to honor God
God will always accept our offerings regardless
We should rely on our own efforts without prayer
questions.correctAnswer: We should sincerely beseech God for grace and forgiveness
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:9 shows God sarcastically challenging the priests to pray for grace, highlighting the need for genuine repentance and seeking God’s mercy when we have failed.

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 1 teaches that God takes no pleasure in offerings that are given without heart and honor.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:10 clearly states God has no pleasure in offerings made without honor, emphasizing the importance of heartfelt worship.

questions.question: True or False: According to Malachi 1, priests were faithfully honoring God's name and offering pure sacrifices.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6-8 reproves the priests for despising God's name and offering polluted and defective sacrifices, showing their failure to honor God properly.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Malachi 1, God says He hated Esau and loved ______.
options: Jacob
Edom
Israel
The priests
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:2 states God loved Jacob and hated Esau, illustrating His sovereign choice and love.

questions.question: How does Malachi 1 encourage us to view God's name in relation to the nations?
options: God’s name will be great among the Gentiles through pure offerings
God’s name is only for Israel and will not be known by others
The nations will reject God’s name forever
God’s name is unimportant to the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: God’s name will be great among the Gentiles through pure offerings
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:11 promises God's name will be great among the Gentiles, with pure offerings presented everywhere, emphasizing global worship.

questions.question: A believer struggles with contentment in difficult circumstances. Based on Malachi 1:4, what biblical truth can you share?
options: God will oppose those who try to rebuild wickedness and will show His indignation
God ignores the rebuilding efforts of His enemies
We should rely on our own strength to overcome troubles
God promises immediate success to all efforts
questions.correctAnswer: God will oppose those who try to rebuild wickedness and will show His indignation
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:4 describes how God will throw down the rebuilding efforts of Edom, showing His righteous judgment, which teaches trust in God’s sovereign justice amidst trials.

questions.question: How does Malachi 1 teach about the importance of reverence in our service to God and family life?
options: A son should honor his father, just as we should honor God
Family honor is less important than personal desires
Reverence is optional in family and worship
God does not require respect from His people
questions.correctAnswer: A son should honor his father, just as we should honor God
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6 uses the analogy of a son honoring his father to teach the need for respect and reverence toward God, applicable to family and spiritual life.

questions.question: What practical lesson about generosity and stewardship can be drawn from the priests’ failure in Malachi 1?
options: God expects offerings to be given with purity and honor, not negligence
It is acceptable to give defective offerings if we are poor
Giving to God is optional and not important
The amount given matters more than the heart
questions.correctAnswer: God expects offerings to be given with purity and honor, not negligence
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:7-8 rebuke offerings of blind, lame, or sick animals, teaching that God values the quality and heart behind giving, which applies to stewardship.

questions.question: How does Malachi 1 guide believers in maintaining integrity when making vows or commitments to God?
options: Do not vow or sacrifice corrupt things to God
Vows are unimportant and can be broken
It is acceptable to deceive God with offerings
Commitments to God are symbolic only
questions.correctAnswer: Do not vow or sacrifice corrupt things to God
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:14 curses the deceiver who vows and sacrifices corrupt things, teaching the importance of honoring vows with integrity.

hard.title: Malachi Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Malachi Chapter 1.

questions.question: In Malachi 1:2-3, God states He loved Jacob but hated Esau. What is the theological significance of this declaration in the context of divine election?
options: It illustrates God's sovereign choice in election independent of human merit.
It means God literally hates individuals but loves their siblings.
It refers to personal animosity between Jacob and Esau.
It is a metaphor for agricultural blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates God's sovereign choice in election independent of human merit.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:2-3 reflects God's sovereign election, choosing Jacob over Esau not based on works but divine purpose, a theme echoed in Romans 9.

questions.question: Malachi 1:4 mentions Edom's plan to rebuild desolate places but God says He will throw them down. How does this prophecy connect historically to the post-exilic period?
options: It predicts Edom’s failed attempts to restore its territory after exile.
It anticipates the Babylonian destruction of Jerusalem.
It foreshadows Israel’s return from Babylonian captivity.
It describes Egypt's political dominance.
questions.correctAnswer: It predicts Edom’s failed attempts to restore its territory after exile.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:4 addresses Edom’s desire to rebuild, which historically failed after exile, highlighting divine judgment against Edom’s hostility to Israel.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Malachi 1:6 when God compares His relationship with Israel to that of a 'father' and 'master'?
options: Analogy
Hyperbole
Metaphor
Simile
questions.correctAnswer: Analogy
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6 uses analogy to explain the expected honor due to God by comparing it to human relationships like father-child and master-servant.

questions.question: According to Malachi 1:7-8, what is the significance of offering blind, lame, or sick animals as sacrifices?
options: It is an evil act showing contempt for God.
It is acceptable if done with a sincere heart.
It is a tradition from Edom.
It symbolizes repentance.
questions.correctAnswer: It is an evil act showing contempt for God.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:7-8 condemns offering defective animals, emphasizing the requirement for pure and honorable sacrifices as a sign of respect.

questions.question: Malachi 1:10 presents a rhetorical question about shutting doors of the temple for no reason. What cultural practice is this alluding to?
options: The customary opening and closing of temple gates during sacrificial services.
The closing of city gates during war.
The shutting of homes during Sabbath.
The sealing of tombs.
questions.correctAnswer: The customary opening and closing of temple gates during sacrificial services.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:10 refers to the temple gate ritual where doors were opened for sacrifices, indicating priests’ failure to properly honor temple worship.

questions.question: How does Malachi 1:11 foreshadow the universal worship of God beyond Israel?
options: By declaring God's name will be great among the Gentiles and incense offered everywhere.
By predicting the destruction of Gentile nations.
By emphasizing exclusive Israelite worship.
By forbidding Gentiles from worship.
questions.correctAnswer: By declaring God's name will be great among the Gentiles and incense offered everywhere.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:11 predicts the expansion of God’s worship to Gentile nations, anticipating the New Testament mission to all peoples.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'my name is dreadful among the heathen' in Malachi 1:14?
options: It highlights God's majestic power and fearsome reputation among nations.
It means God is hated by heathens.
It refers to God's silence among nations.
It implies God’s name is unknown outside Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights God's majestic power and fearsome reputation among nations.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:14 uses 'dreadful' to express reverence and awe that God's name inspires among the nations, emphasizing His sovereign majesty.

questions.question: True or False: In Malachi 1:6, God accuses the priests of despising His name by failing to show Him honor and fear.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6 explicitly states that the priests despise God's name by not giving Him due honor and reverence.

questions.question: Malachi 1:9 contains a sarcastic prayer asking the priests to 'beseech God' for grace. What does this reveal about their attitude and God’s response?
options: It reveals their hypocritical reliance on God's grace despite disobedience.
It shows sincere repentance and God's immediate forgiveness.
It indicates their rejection of God’s existence.
It praises their faithful service.
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals their hypocritical reliance on God's grace despite disobedience.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:9 demonstrates the priests' presumptuousness in expecting grace while profaning God’s name, prompting God’s rebuke.

questions.question: Which theme in Malachi 1:12-13 is emphasized by the priests calling the Lord's table 'polluted' and showing weariness in their offerings?
options: Profanation of worship and contempt for God.
Joyful celebration of God’s provision.
Strict adherence to sacrificial law.
Hospitality towards strangers.
questions.correctAnswer: Profanation of worship and contempt for God.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:12-13 highlights the priests’ disrespect and contempt through polluted offerings and weariness in worship.

questions.question: What kind of offering does Malachi 1:11 say will be offered from sunrise to sunset among the Gentiles?
options: A pure offering
A burnt offering
A sin offering
A grain offering
questions.correctAnswer: A pure offering
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:11 states that a pure offering will be made to God's name among the Gentiles, indicating true worship.

questions.question: In the opening verse, Malachi 1:1, the term 'burden' (Hebrew 'massa') is used. What does this term typically signify in prophetic literature?
options: A divine oracle or heavy message of judgment.
A joyful prophecy of blessing.
A historical narrative.
An instructional parable.
questions.correctAnswer: A divine oracle or heavy message of judgment.
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'massa' in Malachi 1:1 denotes a heavy or burdened message, often associated with judgment or serious prophetic declarations.

questions.question: How does Malachi 1:5 foreshadow the expansion of God's glory beyond Israel’s borders?
options: It says eyes will see the LORD magnified from Israel’s border.
It predicts the destruction of Israel’s borders.
It commands Israel to conquer neighboring nations.
It limits God’s glory to Israel only.
questions.correctAnswer: It says eyes will see the LORD magnified from Israel’s border.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:5 anticipates recognition of God’s greatness extending beyond Israel, indicating a universal scope of His glory.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural practice do the offerings of blind, lame, and sick animals in Malachi 1:8 contrast with?
options: The requirement for perfect, unblemished sacrifices to deities.
Human sacrifice rituals.
Offering only grain instead of animals.
Sacrifices performed only by kings.
questions.correctAnswer: The requirement for perfect, unblemished sacrifices to deities.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:8 condemns substandard offerings, contrasting Israel’s corrupt sacrifices with the common ancient practice of presenting perfect animals to gods.

questions.question: Malachi 1:14 pronounces a curse on deceivers who sacrifice corrupt animals. What does this reveal about the nature of covenant faithfulness?
options: Covenant faithfulness requires integrity and purity in worship.
Covenant faithfulness is only about external rituals.
It allows for flexible standards in sacrifices.
It focuses solely on personal piety.
questions.correctAnswer: Covenant faithfulness requires integrity and purity in worship.
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:14 underscores that true faithfulness involves honest, pure sacrifices, not deceit or corruption, reflecting the covenant’s moral demands.

theological.title: Malachi Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Malachi Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Malachi 1, how does God express His choice between Jacob and Esau?
options: He loved Jacob and hated Esau
He loved Esau and hated Jacob
He loved both equally
He rejected both
questions.correctAnswer: He loved Jacob and hated Esau
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:2-3 states that the LORD loved Jacob but hated Esau, demonstrating God's sovereign election. This theme aligns with Romans 9:13 and Hebrews 12:16, emphasizing God's sovereign choice and justice.

questions.question: What is the Lord’s response to Edom’s desire to rebuild their desolate places?
options: They shall build, but God will throw down
God will bless their rebuilding efforts
They shall prosper and be exalted
God will remain silent
questions.correctAnswer: They shall build, but God will throw down
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:4 declares that although Edom plans to rebuild, the LORD of hosts will throw down their work and mark them with perpetual indignation, reinforcing God's judgment against persistent rebellion, paralleling Ezekiel 35:12 and Obadiah 1:15.

questions.question: According to Malachi 1, what will the eyes of Israel see regarding the LORD?
options: The LORD will be magnified from the border of Israel
The LORD will abandon Israel
The LORD will punish Israel severely
The LORD will hide His face from Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will be magnified from the border of Israel
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:5 promises that Israel will witness the LORD’s magnification, reflecting God's glory among His people. This anticipates Isaiah 52:10 and the New Testament revelation of Christ's exaltation in Philippians 2:9.

questions.question: What complaint does God make against the priests in Malachi 1?
options: They despise His name and offer polluted bread on His altar
They teach false doctrine
They neglect the poor
They do not pray enough
questions.correctAnswer: They despise His name and offer polluted bread on His altar
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6-7 rebukes the priests for despising God's name by offering defiled sacrifices, violating the holiness required by Leviticus 22:20-25 and echoed in 1 Peter 1:15-16 about being holy as God is holy.

questions.question: How does the LORD describe the offering of blind, lame, and sick animals as sacrifices?
options: It is evil and unacceptable
It is acceptable if given with sincerity
It is better than no offering
It can be accepted after prayer
questions.correctAnswer: It is evil and unacceptable
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:8 condemns offering blind or lame animals, stating it is evil and unacceptable, consistent with Leviticus 22:23-25 and echoed in Isaiah 1:11-17, emphasizing the requirement for pure and honorable worship.

questions.question: What rhetorical question does God ask concerning His honor from His people in Malachi 1?
options: If I am a father, where is my honor?
Why do they not build me a temple?
Why do they not fast and pray?
Why do they love their neighbors?
questions.correctAnswer: If I am a father, where is my honor?
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6 uses the analogy of a son honoring his father to highlight Israel’s failure to honor God, resonating with Exodus 20:12 and Proverbs 3:9 about honoring God as Father and Creator.

questions.question: What does God say about the people's request to beseech Him for grace due to their corrupt offerings?
options: Will He regard their persons because of their corrupt offerings?
He will surely accept their pleas
He will forgive them unconditionally
He is indifferent to their offerings
questions.correctAnswer: Will He regard their persons because of their corrupt offerings?
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:9 questions whether God will accept their pleas when their offerings are corrupt, highlighting that God's acceptance depends on holiness, paralleling Isaiah 59:2 and Hebrews 10:22 on the need for pure hearts.

questions.question: What does God say about offering sacrifices without proper reverence or reason?
options: He has no pleasure and will not accept such offerings
He will accept all offerings out of mercy
He prefers sacrifices over obedience
He will accept sacrifices if done publicly
questions.correctAnswer: He has no pleasure and will not accept such offerings
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:10 states God’s rejection of offerings made without genuine devotion, emphasizing sincere worship as in 1 Samuel 15:22 and Hosea 6:6, where obedience and heart attitude matter most.

questions.question: According to Malachi 1, from where to where shall God's name be great among the Gentiles?
options: From the rising to the going down of the sun
From the north to the south
From the east to the west
From the mountains to the valleys
questions.correctAnswer: From the rising to the going down of the sun
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:11 proclaims God's name will be great among all nations from sunrise to sunset, signifying universal worship, consistent with Psalm 113:3 and the Great Commission in Matthew 28:19.

questions.question: What accusation is made by the people regarding the table of the LORD in Malachi 1?
options: They say it is polluted and its fruit contemptible
They say it is holy and worthy
They say it is too costly
They say it is a place of celebration
questions.correctAnswer: They say it is polluted and its fruit contemptible
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:12 records the people's profaning the LORD’s table by calling it polluted, which reflects disdain for God's provision, contrary to Exodus 29:33 and Isaiah 52:11 about purity and reverence for God's sanctuary.

questions.question: How do the people describe their offerings, reflecting weariness in Malachi 1?
options: As a weariness and they have snuffed at it
As joyful and sincere
As precious and valuable
As holy and acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: As a weariness and they have snuffed at it
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:13 shows their attitude of weariness and contempt for offerings, which God rebukes, paralleling Numbers 15:15 and Isaiah 1:14 that condemn unfaithful worship.

questions.question: What curse does God pronounce in Malachi 1 concerning those who offer corrupt sacrifices after making vows?
options: Cursed be the deceiver who sacrifices corrupt things
Blessed are those who give generously
No curse will come upon those who vow
Only the poor will be cursed
questions.correctAnswer: Cursed be the deceiver who sacrifices corrupt things
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:14 pronounces a curse on those who vow to sacrifice but offer corrupt, unworthy animals, emphasizing God's holiness and justice, in line with Leviticus 27:28-29 and Deuteronomy 23:21-23 on keeping vows.

questions.question: What title does God use for Himself in Malachi 1:14 to emphasize His majesty and fearfulness?
options: A great King
A merciful Father
A humble servant
A silent witness
questions.correctAnswer: A great King
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:14 calls God 'a great King' whose name is dreadful among the nations, highlighting God's sovereign majesty and fearsome holiness, consistent with Psalm 47:7 and Isaiah 33:22.

questions.question: What analogy does God use in Malachi 1 to describe the relationship between Himself and the priests?
options: A father to a son and a master to a servant
A shepherd to his sheep
A king to his subjects
A friend to a friend
questions.correctAnswer: A father to a son and a master to a servant
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:6 uses the analogy of a father and son and master and servant to illustrate the expected honor and fear, emphasizing relational respect due to God, paralleling Exodus 20:12 and Matthew 10:24-25.

questions.question: According to Malachi 1, what will be offered to God in every place among the Gentiles?
options: Incense and a pure offering
Only burnt offerings
Gold and silver
Grain offerings only
questions.correctAnswer: Incense and a pure offering
questions.explanation: Malachi 1:11 promises that incense and pure offerings will be presented to God's name among the Gentiles, indicating universal worship and holiness, consistent with Revelation 5:8 and Psalm 141:2.
